user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_strx_to_uint64_:
```c
size_t
MHD_strx_to_uint64_ (const char *str,
                     uint64_t *out_val)
{
  const char *const start = str;
  uint64_t res;
  int digit;
  if (! str || ! out_val)
    return 0;

  res = 0;
  digit = toxdigitvalue (*str);
  while (digit >= 0)
  {
    if ( (res < (UINT64_MAX / 16)) ||
         ((res == (UINT64_MAX / 16)) &&
          ( (uint64_t) digit <= (UINT64_MAX % 16)) ) )
    {
      res *= 16;
      res += (unsigned int) digit;
    }
    else
      return 0;
    str++;
    digit = toxdigitvalue (*str);
  }

  if (str - start > 0)
    *out_val = res;
  return (size_t) (str - start);
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
digit = toxdigitvalue (*str);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in the shown code. The fragment calls the helper function toxdigitvalue; Rule 17.2 is only broken if MHD_strx_to_uint64_ ends up calling itself. That would occur only if toxdigitvalue (or a function it calls) directly or indirectly calls MHD_strx_to_uint64_ (e.g. toxdigitvalue -> helper -> MHD_strx_to_uint64_), creating recursion. With the provided code fragment (and a normal implementation of toxdigitvalue that just returns a digit value), there is no self-call and thus no Rule 17.2 violation.
